title: How a Father and Son Survived the Devastating Flood Caused by the Remnants of Hurricane Ida
summary: Competitive sailor used life jackets and other gear to swim to safety, save a man who couldn't swim. Griffin Gigliotti, a competitive sailor, has practiced how to ditch a sinking boat. The 18-year-old high-school senior put that know-how to use to escape a Chevy Suburban rapidly taking on water during flash-flooding in the Northeast caused by the remnants of Hurricane Ida.

title: Texas Ruling Raises Doubts About Chief Justice's Hold on the Roberts Court
summary: Looming Mississippi case will put Roe v. Wade directly before Supreme Court with five conservatives steering to right of John Roberts. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court's 5-4 midnight order letting Texas ban most abortions raised new uncertainty about reproductive rights, but one point was clear: It is another sign that Chief Justice John Roberts is struggling to steer the Roberts Court at a time when an even bigger abortion case is looming.

title: 'Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings' Review: Fantastic and Funny
summary: Marvel's latest, starring Simu Liu and Awkwafina, is that rare thing: an almost self-contained superhero movie.

title: 'Who You Think I Am': Catfishing at 50-Something
summary: Juliette Binoche plays a professor of a certain age posing as a younger woman online.

title: Former Minnesota Officer Who Shot Daunte Wright Faces Upgraded Charge
summary: Kim Potter is charged with first-degree manslaughter in case in which she shot Mr. Wright with her Glock 9mm handgun while saying that she would tase him. Kim Potter, the former Brooklyn Center, Minn., police officer who fatally shot Daunte Wright in April with her Glock 9mm handgun while saying that she would tase him will face an additional charge of first-degree manslaughter, Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison said.

title: 'True Crime Story: It Couldn't Happen Here' Review: Big Shocks in Small Towns
summary: A six-part true-crime series looks at murders in seemingly idyllic places. As the title of this six-part series suggests with full ironic intention, the idea that murder and other crimes of violence are unlikely to occur in a small town is alive and well. Notwithstanding the contrary reality so evident in the vivid case histories presented in "True Crime Story: It Couldn't Happen Here." The first three episodes offer rivetingly detailed stories of homicide set, respectively, in the town of Adel, Ga.; the hamlet of Sauquoit, N.Y.; and the (tiny) city of St. Augustine, Fla. The will to murder knows no bounds, as Tony Soprano's creator well understood when he had Tony take time off from a road trip visiting colleges with his daughter for a side trip to strangle a snitch. No explanations were necessary in that fictional series.

title: 'Mogul Mowgli': Sick Verses
summary: Riz Ahmed stars as a Pakistani-British rapper struggling with both his identity and an autoimmune disorder. A rapper hero to the Pakistani diaspora of London, Zed (Riz Ahmed) of the exhilarating "Mogul Mowgli" is a fount of unrelentingly angry rhymes, most of them assailing the persistent outsider status of nonwhites in Britain. But as complicated as his relationship might be with the land of his birth, he at least can give voice to it. More complicated, and suffocating, is his relationship with his parents and his religion and his general cultural ambivalence. All are portrayed by director Bassam Tariq (and his wondrous editors, Hazel Baillie and Adam Biskupski) in a torrent of visual fragments that will marry Zed's experiences to the treacherous clandestine journey taken as a child by his father, Bashir (Alyy Khan), from India to Pakistan during Partition. Add to Zed's problems survivor guilt. And then he gets sick.

title: High Court Abortion Ruling Brings New Uncertainty
summary: Some abortion opponents talk of replicating Texas's law, while abortion-rights supporters pledge to continue fight in court. The Supreme Court's refusal to halt a new restrictive Texas abortion law has plunged the fight over the issue into a new phase of turmoil, with both sides of the issue scrambling to make sense of a legal terrain at its most uncertain since the court recognized a constitutional right to the procedure nearly 50 years ago.

title: 'The Gateway': Helping by Any Means Necessary
summary: Shea Whigham stands out in a talented cast as a social worker gone rogue. Social workers might be thrilled to get a little screen time, though they might not find "The Gateway" or its profoundly antiheroic Parker Jode (Shea Whigham) to be quite the on-screen reflections they're looking for. But the point of director Michele Civetta's uneven but kinetic urban crime drama is that the dedicated Parker is only half a link up the food chain from the people he's trying to help. The people losing their children, or trying to keep them. Who drink and do drugs, like Parker. Carry a gun, like Parker. Who might have been foster kids themselves, like Parker.

title: Simons, Mercer, Others at Renaissance to Pay Up to $7 Billion to Settle Tax Probe
summary: Tax settlement, which current and former executives will personally pay, may be the largest in history. Current and former executives of hedge fund Renaissance Technologies LLC will personally pay as much as $7 billion in back taxes, interest and penalties to settle a long-running dispute with the Internal Revenue Service, the firm said, a tax settlement that may be the largest in history.

summary: The Supreme Court was right not to interfere for now, but the statute won't survive scrutiny on the merits.. America is back fighting its endless legal war over abortion. A new front opened late Wednesday when five Justices issued an unsigned opinion declining to block a Texas law banning abortion after six weeks. Cue the hysterics about the end of abortion rights. But this law is a misfire even if you oppose abortion, and neither side should be confident the law will be upheld.

title: China Plays the Climate Card

summary: As Biden's tax hikes loom, cities and states see a tax-exempt boom.. Democrats in Congress have showered them with federal largesse, and President Biden is now reducing their borrowing costs by driving a stampede of investors into tax-exempt municipal bonds.

summary: Xi Jinping announces new trading venue as U.S. listing opportunities dwindle. title: Communism, Secularism and Jewish Schools
summary: My grandfather fled the Soviet Union for the liberty New York wants to deny me.. After the Russian Revolution, the Bolsheviks launched a harsh war on religious education throughout the Soviet Union, with devastating consequences for Judaism. To avoid accusations of anti-Semitism, Soviet attacks on traditional Jewish schools, known as cheders or yeshivas, were led by the Yevsektzia, the militant Jewish sections of the Communist Party, whose members were often more ideologically zealous than their gentile counterparts. In an effort to win Jewish hearts and minds, in January 1921 the Yevsektzia organized a particularly grotesque episode called the Trial of the Cheder.

title: Bernie, Bluto and the 'Animal House' Democrats
summary: Spend $5 trillion; no one has to pay for it.. Your editorial "Bernie Sanders Runs Out of Billionaires" (Aug. 31) reminds me of the iconic 1978 movie "Animal House." In the film, perennial screw up Bluto Blutarsky tells visitors to the fraternity party: "Grab a brew; don't cost nothin'," betraying an obliviousness to the fact that someone had to pay for the beer being guzzled down. So, too, have the Animal House Democrats adopted such thinking: Spend $5 trillion; no one has to pay for it. In reality, present and future generations will be paying for this frat-party-spending mentality.

title: The Spice Every Cook Needs When Short on Time

title: The American Housing Market Is Stifling Mobility
summary: Prosperous cities use a range of policies to keep home prices high, shutting out newcomers and limiting economic opportunity. Migration has been central to the American story since the beginning. In the early 19th century, New Englanders left the rocky soil of Massachusetts for the more fertile Ohio River valley. During the Dust Bowl of the 1930s, farmers fled Oklahoma for California. In the early 20th century, millions of African-Americans left the Jim Crow South to find work in the factories of northern cities. Through the 20th century, mobility was an American tradition: In every year between 1950 and 1992, according to the Current Population Survey, more than 6% of Americans moved across county lines.

title: Speak No Evil of the S&P 500's Neverending Records

WASHINGTON-Democrats' efforts to pass trillions of dollars in new spending by the end of September are colliding with a pair of other looming deadlines: keeping the government funded and raising the federal borrowing limit to avoid defaulting on debt payments.

title: Grocers Prep for Possible Shortages of Snacks as Mondelez Workers Strike
summary: Retailers stock up on Ritz crackers and turn to other providers in the latest potential supply challenge for food sellers. U.S. grocers are bracing for potential snack food disruptions, as a weekslong strike at Mondelez International Inc. facilities prompts fears of shortages in Ritz crackers and Premium saltines.

title: For the 'Sopranos' Prequel, It's All in the Family
summary: Ahead of 'The Many Saints of Newark,' David Chase, Michael Gandolfini and Alessandro Nivola discuss how the anticipated film was made.. We've never done this," says actor Michael Gandolfini, settling into his chair in a suite at the Beverly Hills Hotel. "We've never sat down, the three of us, and talked about the film."

title: Some Jump the Line for Covid-19 Booster Shots
summary: Those seeking extra doses before they are eligible cite Delta variant, back-to-school season, employers' office reopening plans. U.S. officials have said they expect Covid-19 booster shots to be available for more people beyond the immunocompromised later this month. Some aren't waiting.

title: Custom Armani Suiting, Now For Women
summary: "I thought it was time," says Giorgio Armani of the new series of pieces meant to form a timeless wardrobe.. "I thought it was time," answers Giorgio Armani when asked why, 40 years after his tailoring made him the sartorial authority for elegant men from Hollywood to Wall Street, he's finally offering made-to-order suiting for women.

title: Lithium Booms in the Battle for Electric-Vehicle Batteries
summary: Prices of a key metal compound that underpins the future of the automobile have more than doubled this year. Lithium has a better claim than most commodities to be the "new oil." It even comes with the latest geopolitical baggage.

title: Railroads Brace as Regulator Signals Willingness to Take On Industry
summary: Biden-appointed Surface Transportation Board chairman says aim is to ensure competition, not just 'maximizing profits for railroads'. WASHINGTON-The obscure federal regulator that threw a wrench into a $30 billion railroad merger this week could have more in store for the nation's freight railways-with implications for both business and consumers.

title: Why Bitcoin's Price Got Stuck at $50,000
summary: Investor interest in other corners of the crypto market-including Ethereum and NFTs-has contributed to the lull. The late summer lull that overtakes Wall Street is even making bitcoin drowsy.

title: Enforcing Vaccine Mandates Is Messy Business
summary: Companies find that setting vaccine policies is only the first step: 'There's 101 questions' when it comes to implementing new rules. U.S. companies of all sizes have enacted vaccine requirements for employees in recent weeks. They are finding that setting a policy is more straightforward than enforcing it.

title: Investors, Don't Max Out on Buy Now-Pay Later
summary: Affirm's shares skyrocketed on news of an Amazon partnership-and that begs some questions about the direction of installment payments. Buy now-pay later investors were rewarded for their splurge on these stocks when Affirm Holdings struck a deal with e-commerce behemoth Amazon . com. Now it is time to figure out what exactly they own.

title: Singapore to Host SPAC Listings, in a First Among Asian Financial Hubs
summary: The city-state's enthusiasm for blank-check companies is in contrast with U.S. regulators' hardening stance. Singapore will become the first major financial hub in Asia to allow blank-check companies to list.

title: Medical-Device Stocks Seem Immune to Delta Surge
summary: Higher Covid-19 case counts mean more disruption at hospitals is likely; but this time, Wall Street is ready. Hospitals are facing yet another round of Covid-19 disruptions as the Delta variant spreads across the U.S. That is a concern for the medical-device industry, but investors don't expect to miss a beat.

title: Chewy's Pandemic Run Comes to an End
summary: After capitalizing on last year's interest in pets, the retailer has some new tricks in store. Chewy had a good, enthusiastic run in the markets last year when interaction-deprived humans sought new pets in droves and spent more time online. Now it's time for a breather.

title: Ryan Reynolds's Ad Shop Parent Taps Marketing Vet Joanne Bradford
summary: As chief growth officer, Ms. Bradford is tasked with helping MNTN expand internationally as the advertising technology company plans for possible IPO. Advertising technology company MNTN has named marketing veteran Joanne Bradford to the new role of chief growth officer as the company plans for a possible initial public offering, the company's executives said.

title: Facebook's WhatsApp Fined for EU Privacy Violations
summary: Regulators say chat-service unit failed to disclose fully how it collected and shared data about its users. European Union regulators fined Facebook Inc.'s chat service WhatsApp 225 million euros, equivalent to around $266 million, for failing to tell the bloc's residents enough about what it does with their data, ramping up privacy enforcement against U.S. tech companies.

title: The Netflix Show That Turbocharged Formula One
summary: Renewed for a fourth season, 'Drive to Survive' has brought a new audience to the sport-and they're not there for the cars.. Never before in Formula One's 71 years did motor racing's elite series have a day like last Sunday. As rain lashed down on rural Wallonia, organizers delayed the start of the Belgian Grand Prix race over and over until they risked running out of daytime. When they finally gave the green light, conditions were so dangerous that they stopped the race almost immediately.

title: Industry Groups Urge Lawmakers to Streamline Cyber Breach Reporting Rules
summary: Companies raise concerns about onerous compliance, overly-broad definitions of cyber incidents from multiplying regulatory requirements. The growing body and scope of breach notification rules from regulators, state authorities and soon the federal government risks harming their effectiveness, industry groups warn.

title: The Secrets to Successful Crowdfunding
summary: The failure rate of campaigns is high. Here's how to improve your chances.. Crowdfunding has helped many startups turn creative ideas into innovative products. But the failure rate of crowdfunding campaigns is high. Kickstarter, for instance, says about 61% of completed campaigns on its platform have failed.

title: Hong Kong Venue Bars Outspoken Pop Star, Fearing Beijing Crackdown
summary: Pro-democracy singer Denise Ho loses her stage as concerns grow about artistic expression; film censors may get new powers. HONG KONG-A major nonprofit arts center barred the outspoken pro-democracy Hong Kong pop star Denise Ho from performing just days before a scheduled series of concerts, as concerns grow that a continuing crackdown led by Beijing could stifle artistic expression in the city.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Stocks Rise After Economic Data
summary: S&P 500, Nasdaq set records on Thursday. U.S. stocks rose Thursday after fresh data on the labor market and the trade balance showed that the economic recovery remains on track.

title: 'Up, Up and Away' Was Nearly a Teen-Movie Theme Song
summary: The '67 multi-Grammy-winning hit sent the careers of Jimmy Webb and the 5th Dimension into orbit. Jimmy Webb wrote "Up, Up and Away" in 1965, when he was in college and struggling to make ends meet. Originally a theme for a teen-movie concept, the song was recorded by the 5th Dimension in 1967 for their first album.

title: Apple to Allow Media Apps to Link to Own Websites for Payments
summary: Spotify and other technology companies for years have said Apple's restrictions were unfair and anticompetitive. Apple Inc. said it would allow media apps to create in-app links to sign-up pages on those companies' websites, allowing the likes of Spotify Technology SA and Netflix Inc. to bypass the iPhone maker's cut of subscriptions.

title: New York Poised to Join Ranks of States Extending Eviction Ban
summary: Lawmakers say move would allow more time to distribute rental assistance funds. ALBANY, N. Y.-New York lawmakers passed a bill Wednesday to extend the state's eviction moratorium until Jan. 15, a move they said would give officials more time to distribute rental assistance funds after the Supreme Court struck down federal protections last month.

title: Joe Rogan Says He Tested Positive for Covid-19
summary: Podcaster said he started showing symptoms Saturday night and used several treatments. Joe Rogan, the popular podcast host, said Wednesday on his Instagram page that he tested positive for Covid-19.

title: Investors Sue Oppenheimer Over Alleged Ponzi Scheme
summary: A class-action suit claims the bank bears responsibility for a $110 million fraud an ex-employee started while working for the bank. A class-action lawsuit claims investment bank Oppenheimer & Co. Inc. was at fault for an alleged Ponzi scheme run by a former employee, which authorities say collected $110 million from unwitting investors.
